<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Vegetarianism skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Vegetarianism</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:About&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:About (page does not exist)">Template:About</a>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Use_mdy_dates&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Use mdy dates (page does not exist)">Template:Use mdy dates</a>{{#invoke:Infobox|infobox}}
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Vegan_Gardein_Tofu_Foods_Display_(cropped1).jpg" title="File:Vegan Gardein Tofu Foods Display (cropped1).jpg">File:Vegan Gardein Tofu Foods Display (cropped1).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A variety of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vegan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vegan (page does not exist)">vegan</a> and vegetarian <a href="/wiki/Delicatessen" title="Delicatessen">deli</a> foods.</div></div></div>
<p><b>Vegetarianism</b> is the practice of abstaining from the consumption of  <a href="/wiki/Meat" title="Meat">meat</a>&#160;– <a href="/wiki/Red_meat" title="Red meat">red meat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Poultry" title="Poultry">poultry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seafood" title="Seafood">seafood</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Flesh" title="Flesh">flesh</a> of any other <a href="/w/index.php?title=Animal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Animal (page does not exist)">animal</a>; it may also include abstention from <a href="/wiki/By-product" title="By-product">by-products</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Animal_slaughter&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Animal slaughter (page does not exist)">animal slaughter</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-vegsoc.org_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vegsoc.org-1">[1]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ivu.org_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ivu.org-2">[2]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-navs-online.org_3-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-navs-online.org-3">[3]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Forrest_4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Forrest-4">[4]</a></sup>
</p><p>Vegetarianism can be adopted for different reasons. Many <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ethics_of_eating_meat&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ethics of eating meat (page does not exist)">object to eating meat</a> out of respect for <a href="/wiki/Sentience" title="Sentience">sentient</a> life. Such ethical motivations have been codified <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vegetarianism_and_religion&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vegetarianism and religion (page does not exist)">under various religious beliefs</a>, along with the concept of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Animal_rights&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Animal rights (page does not exist)">animal rights</a>. Other motivations for vegetarianism are health-related, political, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Environmental_vegetarianism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Environmental vegetarianism (page does not exist)">environmental</a>, cultural, <a href="/wiki/Aesthetics" title="Aesthetics">aesthetic</a> or <a href="/wiki/Economic_vegetarianism" title="Economic vegetarianism">economic</a>. There are varieties of the diet as well: an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ovo_vegetarianism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ovo vegetarianism (page does not exist)">ovo-vegetarian</a> diet includes eggs but not dairy products, a <a href="/wiki/Lacto_vegetarianism" title="Lacto vegetarianism">lacto-vegetarian</a> diet includes dairy products but not eggs, and an <a href="/wiki/Ovo-lacto_vegetarianism" title="Ovo-lacto vegetarianism">ovo-lacto vegetarian</a> diet includes both eggs and dairy products. A <a href="/wiki/Veganism" title="Veganism">vegan</a>, or strict vegetarian, diet excludes all <a href="/w/index.php?title=Animal_product&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Animal product (page does not exist)">animal products</a>, including eggs, dairy, beeswax and honey. Some vegans also avoid animal products such as leather for clothing and goose-fat for shoe polish.
</p><p>Various packaged or processed foods, including cake, cookies, candies, chocolate, yogurt and marshmallows, often contain unfamiliar animal ingredients, and may be a special concern for vegetarians due to the likelihood of such additions.<sup id="cite_ref-navs-online.org_3-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-navs-online.org-3">[3]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-vegsoc.org2_5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vegsoc.org2-5">[5]</a></sup> Often, products are reviewed by vegetarians for animal-derived ingredients prior to purchase or consumption.<sup id="cite_ref-vegsoc.org2_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vegsoc.org2-5">[5]</a></sup> Vegetarians vary in their feelings regarding these ingredients, however. For example, while some vegetarians may be unaware of animal-derived rennet's role in the usual production of cheese and may therefore unknowingly consume the product,<sup id="cite_ref-navs-online.org_3-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-navs-online.org-3">[3]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-vrg.org_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vrg.org-6">[6]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-vrg_faq_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vrg_faq-7">[7]</a></sup> other vegetarians may not take issue with its consumption.<sup id="cite_ref-navs-online.org_3-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-navs-online.org-3">[3]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Forrest_4-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Forrest-4">[4]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Semi-vegetarianism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Semi-vegetarianism (page does not exist)">Semi-vegetarian</a> diets consist largely of vegetarian foods, but may include fish or poultry, or sometimes other meats, on an infrequent basis. Those with diets containing fish or poultry may define <i>meat</i> only as <a href="/wiki/Mammal" title="Mammal">mammalian</a> flesh and may identify with vegetarianism.<sup id="cite_ref-Shorter_Oxford_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Shorter_Oxford-8">[8]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Barr_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Barr-9">[9]</a></sup> A <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pescetarianism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pescetarianism (page does not exist)">pescetarian</a> diet has been described as "fish but no other meat".<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Colloquialism" title="Colloquialism">common use</a> association between such diets and vegetarianism has led vegetarian groups such as the <a href="/wiki/Vegetarian_Society" title="Vegetarian Society">Vegetarian Society</a> to state that diets containing these ingredients are not vegetarian, due to fish and birds being animals.<sup id="cite_ref-Vegsoc.org.2C_fish_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vegsoc.org.2C_fish-11">[11]</a></sup>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:TOC_limit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:TOC limit (page does not exist)">Template:TOC limit</a>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Vegetarian_Society" title="Vegetarian Society">Vegetarian Society</a>, founded in Manchester, UK in 1847, says that the word <i>vegetarian</i> is derived from the Latin word <i>vegetus,</i> meaning lively or vigorous.<sup id="cite_ref-vegetus_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vegetus-12">[12]</a></sup> In contrast, the <i><a href="/wiki/Oxford_English_Dictionary" title="Oxford English Dictionary">Oxford English Dictionary</a></i> (<i>OED</i>) and other standard dictionaries state that the word was formed from the term <i>vegetable</i> and the suffix "-arian".<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> The <i>OED</i> writes that the word came into general use after the formation of the Vegetarian Society at Ramsgate in 1847, though it offers two examples of usage from 1839 and 1842.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> The 1839 occurrence still is under discussion,<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup> but the International Vegetarian Society's History group reported 8 other printed occurrences, prior to the Vegetarian Society's foundation in 1847.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The earliest records of (lacto) vegetarianism come from ancient <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">ancient Greece</a> in the 5th century BCE.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> In  the Asian instance the diet was closely connected with the idea of <a href="/wiki/Nonviolence" title="Nonviolence">nonviolence</a> towards animals (called <i><a href="/wiki/Ahimsa" title="Ahimsa">ahimsa</a></i> in India) and was promoted by religious groups and philosophers.<sup id="cite_ref-rv_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rv-18">[18]</a></sup> Among the <a href="/wiki/Hellenes" title="Hellenes" class="mw-redirect">Hellenes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">Egyptians</a> and others, it had medical or <a href="/wiki/Ritual_purification" title="Ritual purification">Ritual purification</a> purposes.
</p>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_subcontinent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indian subcontinent (page does not exist)">Indian</a> emperor <a href="/wiki/Ashoka" title="Ashoka">Ashoka</a> asserted protection to fauna: <blockquote class="templatequote">"Twenty-six years after my coronation various animals were declared to be protected – parrots, mainas, <i>aruna</i>, ruddy geese, wild ducks, <i>nandimukhas, gelatas</i>, bats, queen ants, terrapins, boneless fish, <i>vedareyaka</i>, <i>gangapuputaka</i>, <i>sankiya</i> fish, tortoises, porcupines, squirrels, deer, bulls, <i>okapinda</i>, wild asses, wild pigeons, domestic pigeons and all four-footed creatures that are neither useful nor edible. Those nanny goats, ewes and sows which are with young or giving milk to their young are protected, and so are young ones less than six months old. Cocks are not to be caponized, husks hiding living beings are not to be burnt and forests are not to be burnt either without reason or to kill creatures. One animal is not to be fed to another." —<i><a href="/wiki/Edicts_of_Ashoka" title="Edicts of Ashoka">Edicts of Ashoka</a></i>, Fifth Pillar
</blockquote>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:India_vegetarian_labels.svg" title="File:India vegetarian labels.svg">File:India vegetarian labels.svg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Labeling is mandatory in India<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> to distinguish vegetarian products (green) from non-vegetarian products (brown).</div></div></div>
<p>Following the Christianisation of the Roman Empire in late antiquity, vegetarianism practically disappeared from Europe as it was in other Continents, except India.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup> Several orders of monks in <a href="/wiki/Medieval_Europe" title="Medieval Europe" class="mw-redirect">medieval Europe</a> restricted or banned the consumption of meat for <a href="/wiki/Asceticism" title="Asceticism">ascetic</a> reasons, but none of them eschewed fish.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup> (The medieval definition of "fish" included such animals as seals, porpoises, dolphins, barnacle geese, puffins, and beavers.)<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup>
</p><p>It re-emerged during the <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> becoming more widespread in the 19th and 20th centuries. In 1847, the first <a href="/wiki/Vegetarian_Society" title="Vegetarian Society">Vegetarian Society</a> was founded in the United Kingdom;<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup> Germany, the Netherlands, and other countries followed. The <a href="/wiki/International_Vegetarian_Union" title="International Vegetarian Union">International Vegetarian Union</a>, a union of the national societies, was founded in 1908. In the Western world, the popularity of vegetarianism grew during the 20th century as a result of nutritional, ethical, and more recently, environmental and economic concerns.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Varieties_of_vegetarianism">Varieties of vegetarianism</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Non_eggetarian.jpg" title="File:Non eggetarian.jpg">File:Non eggetarian.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Roadside café near <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kullu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kullu (page does not exist)">Kullu</a>, India.</div></div></div>
<p>There are a number of types of vegetarianism, which exclude or include various foods.
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ovo_vegetarianism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ovo vegetarianism (page does not exist)">Ovo vegetarianism</a> includes eggs but not dairy products.
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Lacto_vegetarianism" title="Lacto vegetarianism">Lacto vegetarianism</a> includes dairy products but not eggs.
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Ovo-lacto_vegetarianism" title="Ovo-lacto vegetarianism">Ovo-lacto vegetarianism</a> (or lacto-ovo vegetarianism) includes animal/dairy products such as eggs, milk, and honey.
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Veganism" title="Veganism">Veganism</a> excludes all animal flesh and products, such as milk, honey, and eggs, as well as items refined or manufactured through any such product, such as bone-char refined white sugar or animal-tested baking soda.
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Raw_veganism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Raw veganism (page does not exist)">Raw veganism</a> includes only fresh and uncooked fruit, nuts, seeds, and vegetables. Vegetables can only be cooked up to a certain temperature.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Fruitarianism" title="Fruitarianism">Fruitarianism</a> permits only fruit, nuts, seeds, and other plant matter that can be gathered without harming the plant.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sattvic_diet&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sattvic diet (page does not exist)">Sattvic diet</a> (also known as yogic diet), a plant based diet which may also include dairy (not eggs) and honey, but excludes anything from the <a href="/wiki/Allium" title="Allium">onion or leek family</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lentil" title="Lentil">red lentils</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Durian&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Durian (page does not exist)">durian fruit</a>, mushrooms, blue cheeses, fermented foods or sauces, alcoholic drinks and often also excludes coffee, <a href="/wiki/Tea" title="Tea">black or green tea</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cocoa_bean" title="Cocoa bean">chocolate</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nutmeg" title="Nutmeg">nutmeg</a> or any other type of stimulant such as excess sharp spices.
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Buddhist_vegetarianism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Buddhist vegetarianism (page does not exist)">Buddhist vegetarianism</a>. Different Buddhist traditions have differing teachings on diet, which may also vary for ordained monks and nuns compared to others. Many interpret the <a href="/wiki/Five_Precepts" title="Five Precepts">precept</a> 'not to kill' to require abstinence from meat, but not all.  In Taiwan, su vegetarianism excludes not only all animal products but also vegetables in the <a href="/wiki/Allium" title="Allium">allium</a> family (which have the characteristic aroma of onion and garlic): onion, garlic, scallions, leeks, chives, or shallots.
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jain_vegetarianism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jain vegetarianism (page does not exist)">Jain vegetarianism</a> includes dairy but excludes eggs and honey, as well as root vegetables.
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Macrobiotic_diet" title="Macrobiotic diet">Macrobiotic diets</a> consist mostly of <a href="/wiki/Whole_grain" title="Whole grain">whole grains</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bean" title="Bean">beans</a>.
</li>
</ul>
<p>Within the 'ovo-' groups, there are many who refuse to consume fertilized <a href="/w/index.php?title=Egg_(biology)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Egg (biology) (page does not exist)">eggs</a> (with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Balut_(egg)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Balut (egg) (page does not exist)">balut</a> being an extreme example); however, such distinction is typically not specifically addressed.
</p><p>Some vegetarians also avoid products that may use animal ingredients not included in their labels or which use animal products in their manufacturing; for example, sugars that are whitened with <a href="/wiki/Bone_char" title="Bone char">bone char</a>, cheeses that use animal rennet (enzymes from animal stomach lining), gelatin (derived from the <a href="/wiki/Collagen" title="Collagen">collagen</a> inside animals' skin, bones and <a href="/wiki/Connective_tissue" title="Connective tissue">connective tissue</a>), some <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sugarcane&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sugarcane (page does not exist)">cane</a> sugar (but not <a href="/wiki/Sugar_beet" title="Sugar beet">beet</a> sugar) and apple juice/alcohol clarified with gelatin or crushed shellfish and sturgeon, while other vegetarians are unaware of or do not mind such ingredients.<sup id="cite_ref-navs-online.org_3-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-navs-online.org-3">[3]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Forrest_4-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Forrest-4">[4]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-vegsoc.org2_5-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vegsoc.org2-5">[5]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-vrg.org_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vrg.org-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p><p>Individuals may label themselves "vegetarian" while practicing a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Semi-vegetarianism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Semi-vegetarianism (page does not exist)">semi-vegetarian</a> diet,<sup id="cite_ref-Barr_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Barr-9">[9]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-newsweek.com_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-newsweek.com-27">[27]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> as some dictionary definitions describe vegetarianism as including the consumption of fish, or only include mammalian flesh as part of their definition of meat,<sup id="cite_ref-Shorter_Oxford_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Shorter_Oxford-8">[8]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> while other definitions exclude fish and all animal flesh.<sup id="cite_ref-Vegsoc.org.2C_fish_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vegsoc.org.2C_fish-11">[11]</a></sup> In other cases, individuals may describe themselves as "flexitarian".<sup id="cite_ref-newsweek.com_27-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-newsweek.com-27">[27]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-americandialect.org_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-americandialect.org-30">[30]</a></sup>
These diets may be followed by those who reduce animal flesh consumed as a way of transitioning to a complete vegetarian diet or for health, ethical, environmental, or other reasons. Semi-vegetarian diets include:
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pescetarianism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pescetarianism (page does not exist)">Pescetarianism</a>, which includes fish and possibly other forms of seafood;
</li>
<li> Pollotarianism, which includes chicken and possibly other poultry;
</li>
<li> "Pollo-pescetarian", which includes poultry and fish, or "white meat" only;
</li>
<li> Macrobiotic diet consisting mostly of whole grains and beans, but may sometimes include fish.
</li>
</ul>
<p>Semi-vegetarianism is contested by vegetarian groups, such as the Vegetarian Society, who state that vegetarianism excludes all animal flesh.<sup id="cite_ref-Vegsoc.org.2C_fish_11-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vegsoc.org.2C_fish-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Health_effects">Health effects</span></h2>
<div class="quotebox" style="float: right; clear: right; margin: 0.5em 0 0.8em 1.4em; width: 25%; padding: 6px; border: 1px solid #aaa; font-size: 88%; background-color: #F9F9F9;">
<div style="position: relative; text-align: left;">
<div>
<p>In prospective studies of adults, compared to non-vegetarian eating patterns, vegetarian-style eating patterns have been associated with improved health outcomes—lower levels of obesity, a reduced risk of cardiovascular disease, and lower total mortality. Several clinical trials have documented that vegetarian eating patterns lower blood pressure.
</p><p>On average, vegetarians consume a lower proportion of calories from fat (particularly saturated fatty acids), fewer overall calories, more fiber, potassium, and vitamin C, than do non-vegetarians. Vegetarians generally have a lower body mass index. These characteristics and other lifestyle factors associated with a vegetarian diet may contribute to the positive health outcomes that have been identified among vegetarians.
</p>
</div>
</div>
<div style="text-align: left;"><i>Dietary Guidelines for Americans, 2010</i> – A report issued by the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Department_of_Agriculture" title="U.S. Department of Agriculture" class="mw-redirect">U.S. Department of Agriculture</a> and the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Department_of_Health_and_Human_Services" title="U.S. Department of Health and Human Services" class="mw-redirect">U.S. Department of Health and Human Services</a><sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup></div>
</div>
<p>Scientific endeavors in the area of vegetarianism have shifted from concerns about nutritional adequacy to investigating health benefits and disease prevention.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Academy_of_Nutrition_and_Dietetics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics (page does not exist)">Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dietitians_of_Canada&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dietitians of Canada (page does not exist)">Dietitians of Canada</a> have stated that at all stages of life, a properly planned vegetarian diet is "healthful, nutritionally adequate, and provides health benefits in the prevention and treatment of certain diseases".<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> Large-scale studies have shown that mortality from <a href="/wiki/Ischaemic_heart_disease" title="Ischaemic heart disease" class="mw-redirect">ischaemic heart disease</a> was 30% lower among vegetarian men and 20% lower among vegetarian women than in non-vegetarians.<sup id="cite_ref-Key_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Key-34">[34]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> Vegetarian diets offer lower levels of <a href="/wiki/Saturated_fat" title="Saturated fat">saturated fat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cholesterol" title="Cholesterol">cholesterol</a> and animal protein, and higher levels of carbohydrates, <a href="/wiki/Fiber" title="Fiber">fibre</a>, <a href="/wiki/Magnesium" title="Magnesium">magnesium</a>, <a href="/wiki/Potassium" title="Potassium">potassium</a>, <a href="/wiki/Folate" title="Folate" class="mw-redirect">folate</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Antioxidant" title="Antioxidant">antioxidants</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Vitamin" title="Vitamin">vitamins</a> C and E and <a href="/wiki/Phytochemical" title="Phytochemical">phytochemicals</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup>
</p><p>Vegetarians tend to have lower <a href="/wiki/Body_mass_index" title="Body mass index">body mass index</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> lower levels of cholesterol, lower blood pressure, and less incidence of heart disease, <a href="/wiki/Hypertension" title="Hypertension">hypertension</a>, <a href="/wiki/Diabetes_mellitus_type_2" title="Diabetes mellitus type 2">type 2 diabetes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kidney" title="Kidney">renal disease</a>, <a href="/wiki/Metabolic_syndrome" title="Metabolic syndrome">metabolic syndrome</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup> dementias such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alzheimer%27s_disease&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alzheimer's disease (page does not exist)">Alzheimer's disease</a> and other disorders.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> Non-lean <a href="/wiki/Red_meat" title="Red meat">red meat</a>, in particular, has been found to be directly associated with increased risk of cancers of the <a href="/wiki/Esophageal_cancer" title="Esophageal cancer">esophagus</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Liver_cancer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Liver cancer (page does not exist)">liver</a>, <a href="/wiki/Colon_cancer" title="Colon cancer" class="mw-redirect">colon</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Lung_cancer" title="Lung cancer">lungs</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> Other studies have shown no significant differences between vegetarians and non-vegetarians in mortality from <a href="/wiki/Cerebrovascular_disease" title="Cerebrovascular disease">cerebrovascular disease</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stomach_cancer" title="Stomach cancer">stomach cancer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Colorectal_cancer" title="Colorectal cancer">colorectal cancer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Breast_cancer" title="Breast cancer">breast cancer</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Prostate_cancer" title="Prostate cancer">prostate cancer</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Key_34-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Key-34">[34]</a></sup> A 2010 study compared a group of vegetarian and meat-eating <a href="/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventist_Church" title="Seventh-day Adventist Church">Seventh-day Adventists</a> in which vegetarians scored lower on depression tests and had better mood profiles.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup>
</p><p>The relationship between vegetarian diet and bone health remains unclear. According to some studies, a vegetarian lifestyle can be associated with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_B12_deficiency&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vitamin B12 deficiency (page does not exist)">vitamin B<sub>12</sub> deficiency</a> and low bone mineral density.<sup id="cite_ref-hermann_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hermann-43">[43]</a></sup> However, a study of vegetarian and non-vegetarian adults in Taiwan found no significant difference in bone mineral density between the two groups.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup>  Other studies, exploring animal protein's negative effects on bone health, suggest that vegetarians may be less prone to osteoporosis than omnivores, as vegetarian subjects had greater bone mineral density<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup> and more bone formation.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=China-Cornell-Oxford_Project&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="China-Cornell-Oxford Project (page does not exist)">China-Cornell-Oxford Project</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup> a 20-year study conducted by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cornell_University&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cornell University (page does not exist)">Cornell University</a>, the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Oxford" title="University of Oxford">University of Oxford</a>, and the government of China has established a correlation between  the consumption of animal products and a variety of chronic illnesses, such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Coronary_heart_disease&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Coronary heart disease (page does not exist)">coronary heart disease</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Diabetes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Diabetes (page does not exist)">diabetes</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cancers" title="Cancers" class="mw-redirect">cancers</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Breast" title="Breast">breast</a>, <a href="/wiki/Prostate" title="Prostate">prostate</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bowel" title="Bowel" class="mw-redirect">bowel</a> (see <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_China_Study_(book)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The China Study (book) (page does not exist)">The China Study</a></i>).<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nutrition">Nutrition</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Fruit_Stall_in_Barcelona_Market.jpg" title="File:Fruit Stall in Barcelona Market.jpg">File:Fruit Stall in Barcelona Market.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A fruit stall in <a href="/wiki/Barcelona" title="Barcelona">Barcelona</a></div></div></div>
<p>Western vegetarian diets are typically high in <a href="/wiki/Carotenoid" title="Carotenoid">carotenoids</a>, but relatively low in <a href="/wiki/Omega-3_fatty_acid" title="Omega-3 fatty acid">omega-3 fatty acids</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_B12&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vitamin B12 (page does not exist)">vitamin B<sub>12</sub></a>. Vegans can have particularly low intake of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_B&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vitamin B (page does not exist)">vitamin B</a> and <a href="/wiki/Calcium" title="Calcium">calcium</a> if they do not eat enough items such as <a href="/wiki/Collard_greens" title="Collard greens">collard greens</a>, <a href="/wiki/Leaf_vegetable" title="Leaf vegetable">leafy greens</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tempeh" title="Tempeh">tempeh</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tofu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tofu (page does not exist)">tofu</a> (soy). High levels of dietary fiber, <a href="/wiki/Folic_acid" title="Folic acid">folic acid</a>, vitamins C and E, and magnesium, and low consumption of saturated fat are all considered to be beneficial aspects of a vegetarian diet.<sup id="cite_ref-Key2006_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Key2006-49">[49]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Davey_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davey-50">[50]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Protein">Protein</span></h4>
<p>Protein intake in vegetarian diets is only slightly lower than in meat diets and can meet daily requirements for any person, including athletes and bodybuilders.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup> Studies at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Harvard_University&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Harvard University (page does not exist)">Harvard University</a> as well as other studies conducted in the United States, United Kingdom, Canada, Australia, <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Zealand&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Zealand (page does not exist)">New Zealand</a> and various European countries,
confirmed vegetarian diets provide sufficient protein intake as long as a variety of plant sources are available and consumed.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup> Proteins are composed of <a href="/wiki/Amino_acid" title="Amino acid">amino acids</a>, and a common concern with protein acquired from vegetable sources is an adequate intake of the <a href="/wiki/Essential_amino_acid" title="Essential amino acid">essential amino acids</a>, which cannot be synthesised by the human body. While dairy and egg products provide complete sources for <a href="/wiki/Ovo-lacto_vegetarianism" title="Ovo-lacto vegetarianism">ovo-lacto vegetarian</a>, several vegetable sources have significant amounts of all eight types of essential amino acids, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lupin_bean&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lupin bean (page does not exist)">lupin beans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soybean" title="Soybean">soy</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-SND-soybeans_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SND-soybeans-53">[53]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hemp" title="Hemp">hempseed</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salvia_hispanica" title="Salvia hispanica">chia seed</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-SND-chia_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SND-chia-54">[54]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amaranth_grain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Amaranth grain (page does not exist)">amaranth</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-SND-amaranth_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SND-amaranth-55">[55]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Buckwheat" title="Buckwheat">buckwheat</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-SND-buckwheat_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SND-buckwheat-56">[56]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pumpkin_seeds&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pumpkin seeds (page does not exist)">pumpkin seeds</a><sup id="cite_ref-SND-pumpkin_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SND-pumpkin-57">[57]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Spirulina_(dietary_supplement)" title="Spirulina (dietary supplement)">spirulina</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-SND-spirulina_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SND-spirulina-58">[58]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pistachios&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pistachios (page does not exist)">pistachios</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-SND-pistachio_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SND-pistachio-59">[59]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Quinoa" title="Quinoa">quinoa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-SND-quinoa_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SND-quinoa-60">[60]</a></sup> However, the essential amino acids can also be obtained by eating a variety of complementary plant sources that, in combination, provide all eight essential amino acids (e.g. <a href="/wiki/Brown_rice" title="Brown rice">brown rice</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bean" title="Bean">beans</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Hummus" title="Hummus">hummus</a> and whole wheat <a href="/wiki/Pita" title="Pita">pita</a>, though <a href="/w/index.php?title=Protein_combining&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Protein combining (page does not exist)">protein combining</a> in the same meal is not necessary). A 1994 study found a varied intake of such sources can be adequate.<sup id="cite_ref-young_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-young-61">[61]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Iron">Iron</span></h4>
<p>Vegetarian diets typically contain similar levels of iron to non-vegetarian diets, but this has lower bioavailability than iron from meat sources, and its absorption can sometimes be inhibited by other dietary constituents.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> According to the Vegetarian Resource Group, consuming food that contains vitamin C, such as citrus fruit or juices, tomatoes, or broccoli, is a good way to increase the amount of iron absorbed at a meal.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup> Vegetarian foods rich in iron include <a href="/wiki/Black_turtle_bean" title="Black turtle bean">black beans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cashew" title="Cashew">cashews</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hempseed" title="Hempseed" class="mw-redirect">hempseed</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kidney_bean" title="Kidney bean">kidney beans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Broccoli" title="Broccoli">broccoli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lentil" title="Lentil">lentils</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oatmeal" title="Oatmeal">oatmeal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Raisin" title="Raisin">raisins</a>,  <a href="/wiki/Spinach" title="Spinach">spinach</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cabbage" title="Cabbage">cabbage</a>, lettuce, <a href="/wiki/Black-eyed_pea" title="Black-eyed pea">black-eyed peas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soybean" title="Soybean">soybeans</a>, many <a href="/wiki/Breakfast_cereal" title="Breakfast cereal">breakfast cereals</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sunflower_seed" title="Sunflower seed">sunflower seeds</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chickpea" title="Chickpea">chickpeas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tomato_juice" title="Tomato juice">tomato juice</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tempeh" title="Tempeh">tempeh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Molasses" title="Molasses">molasses</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thyme" title="Thyme">thyme</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Whole-wheat_bread" title="Whole-wheat bread" class="mw-redirect">whole-wheat bread</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup> The related vegan diets can often be higher in iron than vegetarian diets, because dairy products are low in iron.<sup id="cite_ref-Davey_50-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davey-50">[50]</a></sup> Iron stores often tend to be lower in vegetarians than non-vegetarians, and a few small studies report very high rates of iron deficiency (up to 40%,<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup> and 58%<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup> of the respective vegetarian or vegan groups). However, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=American_Dietetic_Association&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="American Dietetic Association (page does not exist)">American Dietetic Association</a> states that iron deficiency is no more common in vegetarians than non-vegetarians (adult males are rarely iron deficient); iron deficiency <a href="/wiki/Anemia" title="Anemia">anaemia</a> is rare no matter the diet.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Vitamin_B12">Vitamin B<sub>12</sub></span></h4>
<p>According to the United States <a href="/wiki/National_Institutes_of_Health" title="National Institutes of Health">National Institutes of Health</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_B12&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vitamin B12 (page does not exist)">vitamin B<sub>12</sub></a> is not generally present in plants and is naturally found in foods of animal origin.<sup id="cite_ref-ODS_B12_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODS_B12-68">[68]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ovo-lacto_vegetarianism" title="Ovo-lacto vegetarianism">Lacto-ovo vegetarians</a> can obtain B<sub>12</sub> from dairy products and eggs, and vegans can obtain it from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fortified_food&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fortified food (page does not exist)">fortified foods</a> (including some soy products and some breakfast cereals) and dietary supplements.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Vegan_Society_B12_factsheet_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vegan_Society_B12_factsheet-71">[71]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-donaldson_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-donaldson-72">[72]</a></sup> Vitamin B<sub>12</sub> can also be obtained from fortified <a href="/wiki/Yeast" title="Yeast">yeast</a> extract products.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup>
</p><p>The recommended dietary allowance of B<sub>12</sub> in the United States is, per day, 0.4 mcg (0–6 months), rising to 1.8 mcg (9–13 years), 2.4 mcg (14+ years), and 2.8 mcg (lactating female).<sup id="cite_ref-ODS_B12_68-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ODS_B12-68">[68]</a></sup> While the body's daily requirement for vitamin B<sub>12</sub> is very small, deficiency of the vitamin is very serious leading to anemia and irreversible nerve damage.<sup id="cite_ref-moz_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-moz-74">[74]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Fatty_acids">Fatty acids</span></h4>
<p>Plant-based, or vegetarian, sources of <a href="/wiki/Omega_3" title="Omega 3" class="mw-redirect">Omega 3</a> fatty acids include <a href="/wiki/Soy" title="Soy" class="mw-redirect">soy</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Walnut&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Walnut (page does not exist)">walnuts</a>, pumpkin seeds, <a href="/wiki/Canola_oil" title="Canola oil" class="mw-redirect">canola oil</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kiwifruit" title="Kiwifruit">kiwifruit</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hempseed" title="Hempseed" class="mw-redirect">hempseed</a>, <a href="/wiki/Algae" title="Algae">algae</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chia_seed&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chia seed (page does not exist)">chia seed</a>, <a href="/wiki/Flaxseed" title="Flaxseed" class="mw-redirect">flaxseed</a>, echium seed and <a href="/wiki/Leaf_vegetable" title="Leaf vegetable">leafy vegetables</a> such as lettuce, <a href="/wiki/Spinach" title="Spinach">spinach</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cabbage" title="Cabbage">cabbage</a> and <a href="/wiki/Portulaca_oleracea" title="Portulaca oleracea">purslane</a>. Purslane contains more Omega 3 than any other known leafy green. <a href="/wiki/Olive" title="Olive">Olives</a> (and <a href="/wiki/Olive_oil" title="Olive oil">olive oil</a>) are another important plant source of unsaturated fatty acids. Plant foods can provide <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alpha-linolenic_acid&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alpha-linolenic acid (page does not exist)">alpha-linolenic acid</a> which the human body uses to synthesize the long-chain n-3 fatty acids <a href="/wiki/Eicosapentaenoic_acid" title="Eicosapentaenoic acid">EPA</a> and <a href="/wiki/Docosahexaenoic_acid" title="Docosahexaenoic acid">DHA</a>. EPA and DHA can be obtained directly in high amounts from oily fish or fish oils. Vegetarians, and particularly vegans, have lower levels of EPA and DHA than meat-eaters. While the health effects of low levels of EPA and DHA are unknown, it is unlikely that supplementation with alpha-linolenic acid will significantly increase levels.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Clarify&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Clarify (page does not exist)">Template:Clarify</a> Recently, some companies have begun to market vegetarian DHA supplements containing seaweed extracts. Similar supplements providing both DHA and EPA have also begun to appear.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup> Whole seaweeds are not suitable for supplementation because their high iodine content limits the amount that may be safely consumed. However, certain <a href="/wiki/Algae" title="Algae">algae</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Spirulina_(dietary_supplement)" title="Spirulina (dietary supplement)">spirulina</a> are good sources of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gamma-linolenic_acid&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gamma-linolenic acid (page does not exist)">gamma-linolenic acid</a> (GLA), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alpha-linolenic_acid&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alpha-linolenic acid (page does not exist)">alpha-linolenic acid</a> (ALA), <a href="/wiki/Linoleic_acid" title="Linoleic acid">linoleic acid</a> (LA), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Stearidonic_acid&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stearidonic acid (page does not exist)">stearidonic acid</a> (SDA), <a href="/wiki/Eicosapentaenoic_acid" title="Eicosapentaenoic acid">eicosapentaenoic acid</a> (EPA), <a href="/wiki/Docosahexaenoic_acid" title="Docosahexaenoic acid">docosahexaenoic acid</a> (DHA), and <a href="/wiki/Arachidonic_acid" title="Arachidonic acid">arachidonic acid</a> (AA).<sup id="cite_ref-uzbek_77-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-uzbek-77">[77]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-biomass_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-biomass-78">[78]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Calcium">Calcium</span></h4>
<p><a href="/wiki/Calcium" title="Calcium">Calcium</a> intake in vegetarians is similar to non-vegetarians. Some impaired bone mineralisation has been found among vegans who do not consume enough leafy greens, which are sources of abundant calcium.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup> However, this is not found in lacto-ovo vegetarians.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup> Some significant sources of calcium include <a href="/wiki/Broccoli" title="Broccoli">broccoli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bean" title="Bean">beans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pea" title="Pea">peas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lentil" title="Lentil">lentils</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cabbage" title="Cabbage">cabbage</a>, lettuce, <a href="/wiki/Collard_greens" title="Collard greens">collard greens</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chinese_cabbage" title="Chinese cabbage">bok choy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kale" title="Kale">kale</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Turnip" title="Turnip">turnip greens</a>. <a href="/wiki/Spinach" title="Spinach">Spinach</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Swiss_chard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Swiss chard (page does not exist)">swiss chard</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Beet&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Beet (page does not exist)">beet greens</a> are high in calcium, but the calcium is bound to oxalate and therefore it is poorly absorbed.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Vitamin_D">Vitamin D</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Vitamin D needs can be met via the human body's own generation upon sufficient and sensible  exposure to ultraviolet (UV) light in sunlight.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup> Products including milk, <a href="/wiki/Soy_milk" title="Soy milk">soy milk</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cereal_grain" title="Cereal grain" class="mw-redirect">cereal grains</a> may be <a href="/w/index.php?title=Food_fortification&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Food fortification (page does not exist)">fortified</a> to provide a source of Vitamin D<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup> For those who do not get adequate sun exposure and/or food sources, Vitamin D supplementation may be necessary.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Vitamin_D2">Vitamin D<sub>2</sub></span></h4>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Plants" title="Plants" class="mw-redirect">Plants</a>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Alfalfa" title="Alfalfa">Alfalfa</a> (<i>Medicago sativa subsp. sativa</i>), shoot: 4.8 μg (192 IU) vitamin D<sub>2</sub>, 0.1 μg (4 IU) vitamin D<sub>3</sub><sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fungus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fungus (page does not exist)">Fungus</a>, from USDA nutrient database:<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li> Mushrooms, portabella, exposed to <a href="/wiki/Ultraviolet_light" title="Ultraviolet light" class="mw-redirect">ultraviolet light</a>, raw: Vitamin D<sub>2</sub>: 11.2 μg (446 IU)
</li>
<li> Mushrooms, portabella, exposed to ultraviolet light, grilled: Vitamin D<sub>2</sub>: 13.1 μg (524 IU)
</li>
<li> Mushrooms, shiitake, dried: Vitamin D<sub>2</sub>: 3.9 μg (154 IU)
</li>
<li> Mushrooms, shiitake, raw: Vitamin D<sub>2</sub>: 0.4 μg (18 IU)
</li>
<li> Mushrooms, portabella, raw: Vitamin D<sub>2</sub>: 0.3 μg (10 IU)
</li>
<li> Mushroom powder, any species, illuminated with sunlight or artificial ultraviolet light sources
</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<p>Vitamin D<sub>2</sub>, or <a href="/wiki/Ergocalciferol" title="Ergocalciferol">ergocalciferol</a> is found in fungus (except <a href="/wiki/Alfalfa" title="Alfalfa">alfalfa</a> which is a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plantae&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Plantae (page does not exist)">plantae</a>) and created from <a href="/wiki/Viosterol" title="Viosterol" class="mw-redirect">viosterol</a>, which in turn is created when ultraviolet light activates <a href="/wiki/Ergosterol" title="Ergosterol">ergosterol</a> (which is found in fungi and named as a <a href="/wiki/Sterol" title="Sterol">sterol</a> from <a href="/wiki/Ergot" title="Ergot">ergot</a>). Any <a href="/wiki/Ultraviolet_light" title="Ultraviolet light" class="mw-redirect">UV</a>-irradiated fungus including <a href="/wiki/Yeast" title="Yeast">yeast</a> form vitamin D<sub>2</sub>.<sup id="cite_ref-Bowerman_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Bowerman-87">[87]</a></sup> Human bioavailability of vitamin D<sub>2</sub> from vitamin D<sub>2</sub>-enhanced button mushrooms via UV-B irradiation is effective in improving vitamin D status and not different from a vitamin D<sub>2</sub> supplement according to study.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup> For example, Vitamin D<sub>2</sub> from UV-irradiated yeast baked into bread is bioavailable.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup>
By visual assessment or using a chromometer, no significant discoloration of irradiated mushrooms, as measured by the degree of "whiteness", was observed<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> making it hard to discover if they have been treated without labeling. Claims have been made that a normal serving (approx. 3 oz or 1/2 cup, or 60 grams) of mushrooms treated with ultraviolet light increase their vitamin D content to levels up to 80 micrograms,<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup> or 2700 IU if exposed to just 5 minutes of UV light after being harvested.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Longevity">Longevity</span></h3>
<p>A 1999 <a href="/wiki/Meta-analysis" title="Meta-analysis">metastudy</a> combined data from five studies from western countries.<sup id="cite_ref-AJCN_metastudy_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AJCN_metastudy-93">[93]</a></sup> The metastudy reported <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mortality_ratio&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mortality ratio (page does not exist)">mortality ratios</a>, where lower numbers indicated fewer deaths, for fish eaters to be 0.82, vegetarians to be 0.84, occasional meat eaters (eat meat less than once per week) to be 0.84. Regular meat eaters had the base mortality rate of 1.0, while the number for <a href="/wiki/Veganism" title="Veganism">vegans</a> was very uncertain (anywhere between 0.7 and 1.44) due to too few data points. The study reported the numbers of deaths in each category, and expected error ranges for each ratio, and adjustments made to the data. However, the "lower mortality was due largely to the relatively low prevalence of smoking in these [vegetarian] cohorts". Out of the major causes of death studied, only one difference in mortality rate was attributed to the difference in diet, as the conclusion states: "...vegetarians had a 24% lower mortality from <a href="/wiki/Ischaemic_heart_disease" title="Ischaemic heart disease" class="mw-redirect">ischaemic heart disease</a> than non-vegetarians, but no associations of a vegetarian diet with other major causes of death were established".<sup id="cite_ref-AJCN_metastudy_93-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AJCN_metastudy-93">[93]</a></sup>
</p><p>In <i>Mortality in British vegetarians</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-AJCN_British_study_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AJCN_British_study-94">[94]</a></sup> a similar conclusion is drawn: "British vegetarians have low mortality compared with the general population. Their death rates are similar to those of comparable non-vegetarians, suggesting that much of this benefit may be attributed to non-dietary lifestyle factors such as a low prevalence of smoking and a generally high socio-economic status, or to aspects of the diet other than the avoidance of meat and fish."<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Adventist_Health_Studies&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Adventist Health Studies (page does not exist)">Adventist Health Studies</a> is ongoing research that documents the <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">life expectancy</a> in <a href="/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventist_Church" title="Seventh-day Adventist Church">Seventh-day Adventists</a>. This is the only study among others with similar methodology which had favourable indication for vegetarianism. The researchers found that a combination of different lifestyle choices could influence life expectancy by as much as 10 years. Among the lifestyle choices investigated, a vegetarian diet was estimated to confer an extra 1–1/2 to 2 years of life. The researchers concluded that "the life expectancies of California Adventist men and women are higher than those of any other well-described natural population" at 78.5 years for men and 82.3 years for women. The life expectancy of California Adventists surviving to age 30 was 83.3 years for men and 85.7 years for women.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Adventist health study is again incorporated into a metastudy titled "Does low meat consumption increase life expectancy in humans?" published in <i>American Journal of Clinical Nutrition</i>, which concluded that low meat eating (less than once per week) and other lifestyle choices significantly increase life expectancy, relative to a group with high meat intake. The study concluded that "The findings from one cohort of healthy adults raises the possibility that long-term (≥ 2 decades) adherence to a vegetarian diet can further produce a significant 3.6-y increase in life expectancy." However, the study also concluded that "Some of the variation in the survival advantage in vegetarians may have been due to marked differences between studies in adjustment for confounders, the definition of vegetarian, measurement error, age distribution, the healthy volunteer effect, and intake of specific plant foods by the vegetarians." It further states that "This raises the possibility that a low-meat, high plant-food dietary pattern may be the true causal protective factor rather than simply elimination of meat from the diet." In a recent review of studies relating low-meat diet patterns to all-cause mortality, Singh noted that "5 out of 5 studies indicated that adults who followed a low meat, high plant-food diet pattern experienced significant or marginally significant decreases in mortality risk relative to other patterns of intake."<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup>
</p><p>Statistical studies, such as comparing <a href="/wiki/Life_expectancy" title="Life expectancy">life expectancy</a> with regional areas and local diets in Europe also have found life expectancy considerably greater in southern France, where a low meat, high plant <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_diet" title="Mediterranean diet">Mediterranean diet</a> is common, than northern France, where a diet with high meat content is more common.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup>
</p><p>A study by the Institute of Preventive and Clinical Medicine, and Institute of Physiological Chemistry looked at a group of 19 vegetarians (lacto-ovo) and used as a comparison a group of 19 omnivorous subjects recruited from the same region. The study found that this group of vegetarians (lacto-ovo) have a significantly higher amount of plasma <a href="/w/index.php?title=Carboxymethyllysine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Carboxymethyllysine (page does not exist)">carboxymethyllysine</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Advanced_glycation_endproducts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Advanced glycation endproducts (page does not exist)">advanced glycation endproducts</a> (AGEs) compared to this group of non-vegetarians.<sup id="cite_ref-Carboxymethyllysine_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Carboxymethyllysine-99">[99]</a></sup> Carboxymethyllysine is a <a href="/wiki/Glycation" title="Glycation">glycation</a> product which represents "a general marker of oxidative stress and long-term damage of proteins in aging, atherosclerosis and diabetes" and "[a]dvanced glycation end products (AGEs) may play an important adverse role in process of atherosclerosis, diabetes, aging and chronic renal failure".<sup id="cite_ref-Carboxymethyllysine_99-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Carboxymethyllysine-99">[99]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Medical_use">Medical use</span></h3>
<p>In <a href="/wiki/Western_medicine" title="Western medicine" class="mw-redirect">Western medicine</a>, patients are sometimes advised to adhere to a vegetarian diet.<sup id="cite_ref-diag_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-diag-100">[100]</a></sup>
Vegetarian diets have been used as a treatment for <a href="/wiki/Rheumatoid_arthritis" title="Rheumatoid arthritis">rheumatoid arthritis</a>, but the evidence is inconclusive whether this is effective.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup>
Certain <a href="/wiki/Alternative_medicine" title="Alternative medicine">alternative medicines</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Ayurveda" title="Ayurveda">Ayurveda</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Siddha_Medicine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Siddha Medicine (page does not exist)">Siddha</a>, prescribe a vegetarian diet as a normal procedure. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maya_Tiwari&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maya Tiwari (page does not exist)">Maya Tiwari</a> notes that <a href="/wiki/Ayurveda" title="Ayurveda">Ayurveda</a> recommends small portions of meat for some people, though "the rules of hunting and killing the animal, practiced by the native peoples, were very specific and detailed". Now that such methods of hunting and killing are not observed, she does not recommend the use of "any animal meat as food, not even for the Vata types".<sup id="cite_ref-ayur_102-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ayur-102">[102]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Physiology">Physiology</span></h3>
<p>Humans are <a href="/wiki/Omnivorous" title="Omnivorous" class="mw-redirect">omnivorous</a>, capable of consuming a wide variety of plant and animal material.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup> Nutritional experts believe that early <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hominidae&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hominidae (page does not exist)">hominids</a> evolved into eating meat as a result of huge climatic changes that took place three to four million years ago, when forests and jungles dried up and became open grasslands and opened hunting and scavenging opportunities.<sup id="cite_ref-milton_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-milton-105">[105]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Animal-to-human_disease_transmissions">Animal-to-human disease transmissions</span></h3>
<p>The consumption of meat can cause a transmission of a number of diseases from animals to humans.<sup id="cite_ref-hill_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hill-107">[107]</a></sup> The connection between infected animal and human illness is well established in the case of <a href="/wiki/Salmonella" title="Salmonella">salmonella</a>; an estimated one-third to one-half of all chicken meat marketed in the United States is contaminated with salmonella.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:R&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:R (page does not exist)">Template:R</a> Only recently, however, have scientists begun to suspect that there is a similar connection between animal meat and human cancer, birth defects, mutations, and many other diseases in humans.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:R&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:R (page does not exist)">Template:R</a><sup id="cite_ref-aflatoxins_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aflatoxins-108">[108]</a></sup> The rate of disease among chickens is so high that the Department of Labor has ranked the poultry industry as one of the most hazardous occupations.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:R&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:R (page does not exist)">Template:R</a> 20% of all cows are afflicted with a variety of cancer known as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bovine_leukemia_virus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bovine leukemia virus (page does not exist)">bovine leukemia virus</a> (BLV).<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:R&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:R (page does not exist)">Template:R</a> Studies have increasingly linked BLV with <a href="/wiki/HTLV-1" title="HTLV-1" class="mw-redirect">HTLV-1</a>, the first human retrovirus discovered to cause cancer.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:R&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:R (page does not exist)">Template:R</a> Scientists have found that a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bovine_immunodeficiency_virus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bovine immunodeficiency virus (page does not exist)">bovine immunodeficiency virus</a> (BIV), the equivalent of the AIDS virus in cows, can also infect human cells.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:R&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:R (page does not exist)">Template:R</a> It is supposed that BIV may have a role in the development of a number of malignant or slow viruses in humans.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:R&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:R (page does not exist)">Template:R</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Clarify&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Clarify (page does not exist)">Template:Clarify</a>
</p><p>The proximity of animals in industrial-scale animal farming leads to an increased rate of disease transmission.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup>
</p>
<blockquote class="templatequote">Transmission of animal influenza viruses to humans has been documented, but illness from such cases is rare compared to that caused by the now common human-adapted older influenza viruses,<sup id="cite_ref-brown_110-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brown-110">[110]</a></sup> transferred from animals to humans in the more distant past.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[nb 1]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[112]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[113]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-pmid18353690_115-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pmid18353690-115">[114]</a></sup> The first documented case was in 1959, and in 1998, 18 new human cases of <a href="/w/index.php?title=H5N1&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="H5N1 (page does not exist)">H5N1</a> influenza were diagnosed, in which six people died. In 1997 more cases of H5N1 avian influenza were found in chickens in Hong Kong.<sup id="cite_ref-brown_110-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-brown-110">[110]</a></sup>
</blockquote>
<p>Whether <a href="/wiki/Tuberculosis" title="Tuberculosis">tuberculosis</a> originated in cattle and was then transferred to humans, or diverged from a common ancestor infecting a different species, is currently unclear.<sup id="cite_ref-Pearce-Duvet_2006_116-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pearce-Duvet_2006-116">[115]</a></sup> The strongest evidence for a domestic-animal origin exists for <a href="/wiki/Measles" title="Measles">measles</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pertussis" title="Pertussis">pertussis</a>, although the data do not exclude a non-domestic origin.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[116]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the 'Hunter Theory', the "simplest and most plausible explanation for the cross-species transmission" the AIDS virus was transmitted from a chimpanzee to a human when a bushmeat hunter was bitten or cut while hunting or butchering an animal.<sup id="cite_ref-Sharp2001_118-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Sharp2001-118">[117]</a></sup>
</p><p>Historian <a href="/wiki/Norman_Cantor" title="Norman Cantor">Norman Cantor</a> suggests the <a href="/wiki/Black_Death" title="Black Death">Black Death</a> might have been a combination of pandemics including a form of <a href="/wiki/Anthrax" title="Anthrax">anthrax</a>, a cattle <a href="/wiki/Murrain" title="Murrain">murrain</a>. He cites many forms of evidence including the fact that meat from infected cattle was known to have been sold in many rural English areas prior to the onset of the plague.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[118]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Eating_disorders">Eating disorders</span></h3>
<p>The American Dietetic Association indicates that vegetarian diets may be more common among adolescents with eating disorders but that the evidence suggests that the adoption of a vegetarian diet does not lead to eating disorders, rather that "vegetarian diets may be selected to camouflage an existing eating disorder".<sup id="cite_ref-adajournal_120-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-adajournal-120">[119]</a></sup> Other studies and statements by dietitians and counselors support this conclusion.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[nb 2]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-veganorexianervosa_123-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-veganorexianervosa-123">[121]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethics_and_diet">Ethics and diet</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="General">General</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Various ethical reasons have been suggested for choosing vegetarianism, usually predicated on the interests of non-human animals. In many societies, controversy and debate have arisen over the ethics of eating animals. Some people, while not vegetarians, refuse to eat the flesh of certain animals due to cultural <a href="/wiki/Taboo" title="Taboo">taboo</a>, such as cats, dogs, horses or rabbits. Others support meat eating for scientific, nutritional and cultural reasons, including religious ones. Some meat eaters abstain from the meat of animals reared in particular ways, such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Factory_farms&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Factory farms (page does not exist)">factory farms</a>, or avoid certain meats, such as <a href="/wiki/Veal" title="Veal">veal</a> or <a href="/wiki/Foie_gras" title="Foie gras">foie gras</a>. Some people follow vegetarian or <a href="/wiki/Veganism" title="Veganism">vegan</a> diets not because of moral concerns involving the raising or consumption of animals in general, but because of concerns about the specific treatment and practises involved in the raising and slaughter of animals, i.e. <a href="/wiki/Factory_farming" title="Factory farming" class="mw-redirect">factory farming</a> and the industrialisation of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Animal_slaughter&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Animal slaughter (page does not exist)">animal slaughter</a>. Others still avoid meat because meat production is claimed to place a greater burden on the environment than production of an equivalent amount of plant <a href="/wiki/Protein" title="Protein">protein</a>.
</p><p>Ethical objections based on consideration for animals are generally divided into opposition to the act of killing in general, and opposition to certain <a href="/wiki/Intensive_farming" title="Intensive farming">agricultural practices</a> surrounding the <a href="/wiki/Animal_husbandry" title="Animal husbandry">production</a> of meat.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethics_of_killing_for_food">Ethics of killing for food</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/wiki/Princeton_University" title="Princeton University">Princeton University</a> professor and founder of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Animal_rights_movement&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Animal rights movement (page does not exist)">animal rights movement</a>, <a href="/wiki/Peter_Singer" title="Peter Singer">Peter Singer</a>, believes that if alternative means of survival exist, one ought to choose the option that does not cause unnecessary harm to animals. Most ethical vegetarians argue that the same reasons exist against killing animals to eat as against killing humans to eat. Singer, in his book <i><a href="/wiki/Animal_Liberation_(book)" title="Animal Liberation (book)">Animal Liberation</a></i> listed possible qualities of sentience in non-human creatures that gave such creatures the scope to be considered under <a href="/wiki/Utilitarianism" title="Utilitarianism">utilitarian ethics</a>, and this has been widely referenced by animal rights campaigners and vegetarians. Ethical vegetarians also believe that killing an animal, like killing a human, can only be justified in extreme circumstances and that consuming a living creature for its enjoyable taste, convenience, or nutritional value is not sufficient cause. Another common view is that humans are morally conscious of their behaviour in a way other animals are not, and therefore subject to higher standards.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[122]</a></sup>
</p><p>Opponents of ethical vegetarianism argue that animals are not <a href="/wiki/Moral_equivalence" title="Moral equivalence">moral equals</a> to humans and so consider the comparison of eating livestock with killing people to be fallacious. This view does not excuse cruelty, but maintains that animals do not possess the rights a human has.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[123]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Milk_and_eggs">Milk and eggs</span></h3>
<p>One of the main differences between a vegan and a <a href="/wiki/Ovo-lacto_vegetarianism" title="Ovo-lacto vegetarianism">typical vegetarian diet</a> is the avoidance of both eggs and <a href="/wiki/Dairy_product" title="Dairy product">dairy products</a> such as milk, cheese, butter and yogurt. <a href="/wiki/Veganism#Ethical_veganism" title="Veganism">Ethical vegans</a> do not consume dairy or eggs because they state that their production causes the animal suffering and/or a premature death.<sup id="cite_ref-marcus_126-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-marcus-126">[124]</a></sup>
</p><p>To produce milk from <a href="/wiki/Dairy_cattle" title="Dairy cattle">dairy cattle</a>, calves are separated from their mothers soon after birth and slaughtered or fed milk replacer in order to retain the cows milk for human consumption.<sup id="cite_ref-milk_127-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-milk-127">[125]</a></sup> Vegans state that this breaks the natural mother and calf bond.<sup id="cite_ref-milk_127-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-milk-127">[125]</a></sup> Unwanted male calves are either slaughtered at birth or sent for <a href="/wiki/Veal" title="Veal">veal</a> production.<sup id="cite_ref-milk_127-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-milk-127">[125]</a></sup> To prolong <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lactation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lactation (page does not exist)">lactation</a>, dairy cows are almost permanently kept pregnant through <a href="/wiki/Artificial_insemination" title="Artificial insemination">artificial insemination</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-milk_127-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-milk-127">[125]</a></sup> After about five years, once the cows milk production has dropped, they are considered "spent" and sent to slaughter for hamburger meat and their hides. A dairy cow's natural life expectancy is about twenty years.<sup id="cite_ref-marcus_126-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-marcus-126">[124]</a></sup>
</p><p>In <a href="/w/index.php?title=Battery_cage&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Battery cage (page does not exist)">battery cage</a> and <a href="/wiki/Free-range_eggs" title="Free-range eggs">free-range egg</a> production, unwanted male <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chick_culling&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chick culling (page does not exist)">chicks are culled</a> or discarded at birth during the process of securing a further generation of egg-laying hens.<sup id="cite_ref-egg_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-egg-128">[126]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Treatment_of_animals">Treatment of animals</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Ethical vegetarianism has become popular in developed countries particularly because of the spread of <a href="/wiki/Factory_farming" title="Factory farming" class="mw-redirect">factory farming</a>, faster communications, and environmental consciousness. Some believe that the current mass demand for meat cannot be satisfied without a mass-production system that disregards the welfare of animals, while others believe that practices like well-managed free-ranging and consumption of game, particularly from species whose natural predators have been significantly eliminated, could substantially alleviate the demand for mass-produced meat.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Classical_Greek_and_Roman_philosophy">Classical Greek and Roman philosophy</span></h3>
<p>Ancient Greek philosophy has a long tradition of vegetarianism. <a href="/wiki/Pythagoras" title="Pythagoras">Pythagoras</a> was reportedly vegetarian (and studied at Mt. Carmel, where some historians say there was a vegetarian community), as his followers were expected to be.
</p><p>Roman writer <a href="/wiki/Ovid" title="Ovid">Ovid</a> concluded his magnum opus <a href="/wiki/Metamorphoses" title="Metamorphoses">Metamorphoses</a>, in part, with the impassioned argument (uttered by the character of Pythagoras) that in order for humanity to change, or <a href="/wiki/Metamorphosis" title="Metamorphosis">metamorphose</a>, into a better, more harmonious species, it must strive towards more humane tendencies. He cited vegetarianism as the crucial decision in this metamorphosis, explaining his belief that human life and animal life are so entwined that to kill an animal is virtually the same as killing a fellow human.
</p>
<blockquote class="templatequote">Everything changes; nothing dies; the soul roams to and fro, now here, now there, and takes what frame it will, passing from beast to man, from our own form to beast and never dies...Therefore lest appetite and greed destroy the bonds of love and duty, heed my message! Abstain! Never by slaughter dispossess souls that are kin and nourish blood with blood!<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[127]</a></sup>
</blockquote>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion_and_diet">Religion and diet</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Vegetarian_Curry.jpeg" title="File:Vegetarian Curry.jpeg">File:Vegetarian Curry.jpeg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Indian_cuisine" title="Indian cuisine">Indian cuisine</a> offers a wide range of vegetarian delicacies because <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a>, practiced by majority of India's populace, encourages vegetarian diet. Shown here is a vegetarian <a href="/wiki/Thali" title="Thali">thali</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jainism</a> teaches vegetarianism as moral conduct as do some major<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[128]</a></sup>
sects of <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a>.
