Buddhism in general does not prohibit meat eating, while <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mahayana&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mahayana (page does not exist)">Mahayana Buddhism</a> encourages vegetarianism as beneficial for developing compassion.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[129]</a></sup> Other denominations that advocate a vegetarian diet include the <a href="/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventist_Church" title="Seventh-day Adventist Church">Seventh-day Adventists</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Rastafari_movement" title="Rastafari movement">Rastafari movement</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ananda_Marga" title="Ananda Marga">Ananda Marga</a> movement and the <a href="/wiki/Hare_Krishnas" title="Hare Krishnas" class="mw-redirect">Hare Krishnas</a>. <a href="/wiki/Sikhism" title="Sikhism">Sikhism</a><sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[130]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[131]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[132]</a></sup> does not equate spirituality with diet and does not specify a vegetarian or meat diet.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[133]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Bah.C3.A1.27.C3.AD_Faith">Bahá'í Faith</span></h3>
<p>While there are no dietary restrictions in the <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%27%C3%AD_Faith" title="Bahá'í Faith">Bahá'í Faith</a>, <a href="/wiki/%60Abdu%27l-Bah%C3%A1" title="`Abdu'l-Bahá">`Abdu'l-Bahá</a>, the son of the religion's founder, noted that a vegetarian diet consisting of fruits and grains was desirable, except for people with a weak constitution or those that are sick.<sup id="cite_ref-PSmith_136-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PSmith-136">[134]</a></sup> He stated that there are no requirements that Bahá'ís become vegetarian, but that a future society should gradually become vegetarian.<sup id="cite_ref-PSmith_136-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PSmith-136">[134]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[135]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[136]</a></sup> `Abdu'l-Bahá also stated that killing animals was contrary to compassion.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:R&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:R (page does not exist)">Template:R</a> While <a href="/wiki/Shoghi_Effendi" title="Shoghi Effendi">Shoghi Effendi</a>, the head of the Bahá'í Faith in the first half of the 20th century, stated that a purely vegetarian diet would be preferable since it avoided killing animals,<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[137]</a></sup> both he and the <a href="/wiki/Universal_House_of_Justice" title="Universal House of Justice">Universal House of Justice</a>, the governing body of the Bahá'ís have stated that these teachings do not constitute a Bahá'í practice and that Bahá'ís can choose to eat whatever they wish but should be respectful of others' beliefs.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:R&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:R (page does not exist)">Template:R</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Buddhism">Buddhism</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Japanese_temple_vegetarian_dinner.jpg" title="File:Japanese temple vegetarian dinner.jpg">File:Japanese temple vegetarian dinner.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A vegetarian dinner at a Japanese Buddhist temple</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Theravadins in general eat meat.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[138]</a></sup> If Buddhist monks "see, hear or know" a living animal was killed specifically for them to eat, they must refuse it or else incur an offense.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[139]</a></sup> However, this does not include eating meat which was given as alms or commercially purchased. In the Theravada canon, Buddha did not make any comment discouraging them from eating meat (except specific types, such as human, elephant, horse, dog, snake, lion, tiger, leopard, bear, and hyena flesh<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[140]</a></sup>) but he specifically refused to institute vegetarianism in his monastic code when a suggestion had been made.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[141]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[142]</a></sup>
</p><p>In several <a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a> texts of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mahayana_Buddhism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mahayana Buddhism (page does not exist)">Mahayana Buddhism</a>, Buddha instructs his followers to avoid meat.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[143]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[144]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[145]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[146]</a></sup> However, each branch of Mahayana Buddhism selects which sutra to follow, and some branches, including the majority of Tibetan and Japanese Buddhists, do eat meat, while many Chinese Buddhist branches do not.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Christianity">Christianity</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>There is no specific teaching on diet in traditional Christianity—except that nothing is forbidden on religious principles. The eating of meat is neither encouraged nor discouraged. Christians have always been free to make their own decisions about what to eat; however, there are groups within Christianity that practice specific dietary restrictions for various reasons.<sup id="cite_ref-Vatican_149-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vatican-149">[147]</a></sup>
</p><p>The early sect known as the <a href="/wiki/Ebionites" title="Ebionites">Ebionites</a> are considered to have practiced vegetarianism. Surviving fragments from their <a href="/wiki/Gospel_of_the_Ebionites#Vegetarianism" title="Gospel of the Ebionites">Gospel</a> indicate their belief that – as Christ is the Passover sacrifice and eating the Passover lamb is no longer required – a vegetarian diet may (or should) be observed. However, orthodox Christianity does not accept their teaching as authentic. Indeed, their specific injunction to strict vegetarianism was cited as one of the Ebionites' "errors".<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[148]</a></sup>
</p><p>At a much later time, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bible_Christian_Church_(vegetarian)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bible Christian Church (vegetarian) (page does not exist)">Bible Christian Church</a> founded by Reverend <a href="/w/index.php?title=William_Cowherd&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="William Cowherd (page does not exist)">William Cowherd</a> in 1809 followed a vegetarian diet.<sup id="cite_ref-desc_151-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-desc-151">[149]</a></sup> Cowherd was one of the philosophical forerunners of the <a href="/wiki/Vegetarian_Society" title="Vegetarian Society">Vegetarian Society</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-history_152-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-history-152">[150]</a></sup> Cowherd encouraged members to abstain from eating of meat as a form of <a href="/wiki/Temperance_(virtue)" title="Temperance (virtue)">temperance</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-oxford_153-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oxford-153">[151]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventist_Church" title="Seventh-day Adventist Church">Seventh-day Adventists</a> are encouraged to engage in healthy eating practices, and ova-lacto-vegetarian diets are recommended by the General Conference of Seventh-day Adventists Nutrition Council (GCNC). They have also sponsored and participated in many scientific studies exploring the impact of dietary decisions upon health outcomes.<sup id="cite_ref-sdada1_154-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sdada1-154">[152]</a></sup> The GCNC has in addition adapted the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_Agriculture" title="United States Department of Agriculture">USDA</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Food_guide_pyramid#USDA_food_pyramid" title="Food guide pyramid">food pyramid</a> for a vegetarian dietary approach.<sup id="cite_ref-sdada1_154-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sdada1-154">[152]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[153]</a></sup> However, the only kinds of meat specifically frowned upon by the SDA health message are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Unclean_animals&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Unclean animals (page does not exist)">unclean meats</a>, or those forbidden in scripture.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[154]</a></sup>
</p><p>Additionally, some <a href="/wiki/Monastic_order" title="Monastic order" class="mw-redirect">monastic orders</a> follow a vegetarian diet, and members of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Orthodox_Church&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Orthodox Church (page does not exist)">Orthodox Church</a> follow a vegan diet during fasts.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[155]</a></sup> There is also a strong association between the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Quakers&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Quakers (page does not exist)">Quakers</a> and vegetarianism dating back at least to the 18th century. The association grew in prominence during the 19th century, coupled with growing Quaker concerns in connection with alcohol consumption, vivisection and social purity. The association between the Quaker tradition and vegetarianism, however, becomes most significant with the founding of the Friends' Vegetarian Society in 1902 "to spread a kindlier way of living amongst the Society of Friends."<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[156]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to Canon Law, Roman Catholics are required to abstain from meat (defined as all animal flesh excluding water animals) on Ash Wednesday, Good Friday, all Fridays of Lent, and all other Fridays (subject to the local bishop) as an act of penance.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Hinduism">Hinduism</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Paths of <a href="/wiki/Hinduism" title="Hinduism">Hinduism</a> hold vegetarianism as an ideal. There are three main reasons for this: the principle of nonviolence (<a href="/wiki/Ahimsa" title="Ahimsa">ahimsa</a>) applied to animals;<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[157]</a></sup> the intention to offer only "pure" (vegetarian) food to a deity and then to receive it back as <a href="/wiki/Prasad" title="Prasad">prasad</a>; and the conviction that a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sattvic_diet&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sattvic diet (page does not exist)">sentient diet</a> is beneficial for a healthy body and mind and that non-vegetarian food is detrimental for the mind and for spiritual development.
</p><p>However, the food habits of Hindus vary according to their community and according to regional traditions. Historically and currently, those <a href="/wiki/Hindus" title="Hindus" class="mw-redirect">Hindus</a> who eat meat prescribe <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jhatka&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jhatka (page does not exist)">Jhatka</a> meat.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[158]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Islam">Islam</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Followers of Islam, or Muslims, have the freedom of choice to be vegetarian for medical reasons or if they do not personally like the taste of meat. However, the choice to become vegetarian for non-medical reasons can sometimes be controversial. Though some more traditional Muslims may keep quiet about their vegetarian diet, the number of vegetarian Muslims is increasing.<sup id="cite_ref-Muslims_can.E2.80.99t_be_vegetarian_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Muslims_can.E2.80.99t_be_vegetarian-161">[159]</a></sup>
</p><p>Vegetarianism has been practiced by some influential Muslims including the Iraqi theologian, female mystic and poet <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rabia_al-Adawiyya&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rabia al-Adawiyya (page does not exist)">Râbi‘ah al-‘Adawîyah of Basrah</a>, who died in the year 801, and the Sri Lankan Sufi master <a href="/wiki/Bawa_Muhaiyaddeen" title="Bawa Muhaiyaddeen">Bawa Muhaiyaddeen</a> who established The Bawa Muhaiyaddeen Fellowship of North America in Philadelphia.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[160]</a></sup> The former <a href="/wiki/President_of_India" title="President of India">Indian president</a> Dr. <a href="/wiki/A._P._J._Abdul_Kalam" title="A. P. J. Abdul Kalam">A. P. J. Abdul Kalam</a> is also famously a vegetarian.<sup id="cite_ref-kalam_163-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kalam-163">[161]</a></sup>
</p><p>In January 1996, The International Vegetarian Union announced the formation of the Muslim Vegetarian/Vegan Society.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[162]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many non-vegetarian Muslims will select vegetarian (or seafood) options when dining in non-<a href="/wiki/Halal" title="Halal">halal</a> restaurants. However, this is a matter of not having the right kind of meat rather than preferring not to eat meat on the whole.<sup id="cite_ref-Muslims_can.E2.80.99t_be_vegetarian_161-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Muslims_can.E2.80.99t_be_vegetarian-161">[159]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Jainism">Jainism</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Followers of <a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jainism</a> believe that all living organisms whether they are micro-organism are living and have a soul, and have one or more senses out of five senses and they go to great lengths to minimise any harm to any living organism. Most Jains are lacto-vegetarians but more devout Jains do not eat root vegetables because they believe that root vegetables contain a lot more micro-organisms as compared to other vegetables, and that, by eating them, violence of these micro-organisms is inevitable. So they focus on eating beans and fruits, whose cultivation do not involve killing of a lot of micro-organisms. No products obtained from dead animals are allowed, because when a living beings dies, a lot of micro-organisms (called as decomposers) will reproduce in the body which decomposes the body, and in eating the dead bodies, violence of decomposers is inevitable. Jain monks usually do a lot of fasting, and when they knew through spiritual powers that their life is very little, they start fasting until death.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[163]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[164]</a></sup> Some particularly dedicated individuals are <a href="/wiki/Fruitarianism" title="Fruitarianism">fruitarians</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[165]</a></sup> Honey is forbidden, because honey is a collection of eggs, excreta, dead bees, and saliva of bees. Some Jains do not consume plant parts that grow underground such as roots and bulbs, because tiny animals may be killed when the plants are pulled up.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[166]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Judaism">Judaism</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BikurimS.jpg" title="File:BikurimS.jpg">File:BikurimS.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Basket of fresh fruit and vegetables grown in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Israel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Israel (page does not exist)">Israel</a></div></div></div>
<p>While it is neither required nor prohibited for Jews to eat meat, a number of medieval scholars of <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Jewish religion</a> (e.g., <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Albo" title="Joseph Albo">Joseph Albo</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Isaac_Arama&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Isaac Arama (page does not exist)">Isaac Arama</a>) regard vegetarianism as a moral ideal, not just because of a concern for the welfare of animals, but because the slaughter of animals might cause the individual who performs such acts to develop negative character traits.  One modern-day scholar who is in favour of vegetarianism is the late Rabbi <a href="/wiki/Abraham_Isaac_Kook" title="Abraham Isaac Kook">Abraham Isaac Kook</a>, the Chief Rabbi of <a href="/w/index.php?title=British_Mandate_for_Palestine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British Mandate for Palestine (page does not exist)">Mandate</a> <a href="/wiki/Palestine" title="Palestine">Palestine</a>. In his writings, Rabbi Kook speaks of vegetarianism as an ideal, and points to the fact that Adam did not partake of the flesh of animals, as all humans and animals were originally commanded by God to only eat plants.<sup id="cite_ref-kook_169-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kook-169">[167]</a></sup> In context, Rabbi Kook makes those comments in his portrayal of the eschatological (messianic) era. However, he personally refrained from eating meat except on the Sabbath and Festivals, and one of his leading disciples, Rabbi <a href="/w/index.php?title=David_Cohen_(rabbi)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="David Cohen (rabbi) (page does not exist)">David Cohen</a>, known as the "<a href="/wiki/Nazirite" title="Nazirite">Nazirite</a>" of Jerusalem, was a devout vegetarian. Several other members of Rabbi Kook's circle were also vegetarians.
</p><p>According to some <a href="/wiki/Kabbalah" title="Kabbalah">Kabbalists</a>, only a mystic, who is able to sense and elevate the reincarnated human souls and "divine sparks", is permitted to consume meat, though eating the flesh of an animal might still cause spiritual damage to the soul. A number of Orthodox Jewish vegetarian groups and activists promote such ideas and believe that the <a href="/wiki/Halakha" title="Halakha">halakhic</a> permission to eat meat is a temporary leniency for those who are not ready yet to accept the vegetarian diet.<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[168]</a></sup>
</p><p><sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[169]</a></sup> The Torah also commands people to ritually slaughter animals when killing them, and goes into precise detail on the rituals of both animal sacrifice and ordinary slaughter (<a href="/wiki/Shechita" title="Shechita">shechita</a>). According to medieval sage Rabbi <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shlomo_Ephraim_Luntschitz&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shlomo Ephraim Luntschitz (page does not exist)">Shlomo Ephraim Luntschitz</a>, author of the Torah commentary <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kli_Yakar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kli Yakar (page does not exist)">Kli Yakar</a>, the complexity of these laws was intended to discourage the consumption of meat.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[170]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Rastafari">Rastafari</span></h3>
<p>Within the Afro-Caribbean community, a minority are <a href="/wiki/Rastafari_movement" title="Rastafari movement">Rastafari</a> and follow the dietary regulations with varying degrees of strictness. The most orthodox eat only "<a href="/wiki/Ital" title="Ital">Ital</a>" or natural foods, in which the matching of herbs or spices with vegetables is the result of long tradition originating from the African ancestry and cultural heritage of Rastafari.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[171]</a></sup> Most Rastafari are vegetarian.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[172]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sikhism">Sikhism</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The tenets of <a href="/wiki/Sikhism" title="Sikhism">Sikhism</a> do not advocate a particular stance on either vegetarianism or the consumption of meat,<sup id="cite_ref-SHP_175-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SHP-175">[173]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[174]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[175]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-hsp_178-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hsp-178">[176]</a></sup> but leave the decision of diet to the individual.<sup id="cite_ref-fool_179-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fool-179">[177]</a></sup> The tenth guru, <a href="/wiki/Guru_Gobind_Singh" title="Guru Gobind Singh">Guru Gobind Singh</a>, however, prohibited "Amritdhari" Sikhs, or those that follow the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sikh_Rehat_Maryada&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sikh Rehat Maryada (page does not exist)">Sikh Rehat Maryada</a> (the Official Sikh Code of Conduct)<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[178]</a></sup> from eating <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kutha_meat&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kutha meat (page does not exist)">Kutha meat</a>, or meat which has been obtained from animals which have been killed in a ritualistic way . This is understood to have been for the political reason of maintaining independence from the then-new Muslim hegemony, as Muslims largely adhere to the ritualistic <a href="/wiki/Halal" title="Halal">halal</a> diet.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:R&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:R (page does not exist)">Template:R</a>
</p><p>"Amritdharis" that belong to some Sikh sects (e.g. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Akhand_Kirtani_Jatha&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Akhand Kirtani Jatha (page does not exist)">Akhand Kirtani Jatha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Damdami_Taksal" title="Damdami Taksal">Damdami Taksal</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Namdhari&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Namdhari (page does not exist)">Namdhari</a><sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[179]</a></sup> and Rarionwalay,<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[180]</a></sup> etc.) are vehemently against the consumption of meat and eggs (though they do consume and encourage the consumption of milk, butter and cheese).<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[181]</a></sup> This vegetarian stance has been traced back to the times of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=British_Raj&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British Raj (page does not exist)">British Raj</a>, with the advent of many new <a href="/wiki/Vaishnava" title="Vaishnava" class="mw-redirect">Vaishnava</a> converts.<sup id="cite_ref-fool_179-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fool-179">[177]</a></sup> In response to the varying views on diet throughout the Sikh population, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sikh_Gurus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sikh Gurus (page does not exist)">Sikh Gurus</a> have sought to clarify the Sikh view on diet, stressing their preference only for simplicity of diet. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Guru_Nanak&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Guru Nanak (page does not exist)">Guru Nanak</a> said that over-consumption of food (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Lobh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lobh (page does not exist)">Lobh</a>, Greed) involves a drain on the Earth's resources and thus on life.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[182]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[183]</a></sup> Passages from the <i><a href="/wiki/Guru_Granth_Sahib" title="Guru Granth Sahib">Guru Granth Sahib</a></i> (the holy book of Sikhs, also known as the <i>Adi Granth</i>) say that it is "foolish" to argue for the superiority of animal life, because though all life is related, only human life carries more importance: "Only fools argue whether to eat meat or not. Who can define what is meat and what is not meat? Who knows where the sin lies, being a vegetarian or a non-vegetarian?"<sup id="cite_ref-fool_179-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fool-179">[177]</a></sup> The Sikh <a href="/wiki/Langar_(Sikhism)" title="Langar (Sikhism)">langar</a>, or free temple meal, is largely lacto-vegetarian, though this is understood to be a result of efforts to present a meal that is respectful of the diets of any person who would wish to dine, rather than out of dogma.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:R&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:R (page does not exist)">Template:R</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Environment_and_diet">Environment and diet</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Environmental vegetarianism is based on the concern that the production of meat and animal products for mass consumption, especially through <a href="/wiki/Factory_farming" title="Factory farming" class="mw-redirect">factory farming</a>, is <a href="/wiki/Environmentalism" title="Environmentalism">environmentally</a> <a href="/wiki/Sustainable_development" title="Sustainable development">unsustainable</a>. According to a 2006 United Nations initiative, the livestock industry is one of the largest contributors to environmental degradation worldwide, and modern practices of raising animals for food contribute on a "massive scale" to air and water pollution, land degradation, climate change, and loss of biodiversity. The initiative concluded that "the livestock sector emerges as one of the top two or three most significant contributors to the most serious environmental problems, at every scale from local to global."<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[184]</a></sup>
</p><p>In addition, animal agriculture is a large source of greenhouse gases. According to a 2006 report it is responsible for 18% of the world's greenhouse gas emissions as estimated in 100-year CO<sub>2</sub> equivalents.  Livestock sources (including enteric fermentation and manure) account for about 3.1 percent of US anthropogenic GHG emissions expressed as carbon dioxide equivalents.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[185]</a></sup>  This EPA estimate is based on methodologies agreed to by the Conference of Parties of the UNFCCC, with 100-year global warming potentials from the IPCC Second Assessment Report used in estimating GHG emissions as carbon dioxide equivalents.
</p><p>Meat produced in a laboratory (called <a href="/wiki/In_vitro_meat" title="In vitro meat">in vitro meat</a>) may be more environmentally sustainable than regularly produced meat.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[186]</a></sup> Reactions of vegetarians vary.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[187]</a></sup> Rearing a relatively small number of grazing animals can be beneficial, as the Food Climate Research Network at Surrey University reports: "A little bit of livestock production is probably a good thing for the environment.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[188]</a></sup>
</p><p>In May 2009, <a href="/wiki/Ghent" title="Ghent">Ghent</a>, Belgium, was reported to be "the first [city] in the world to go vegetarian at least once a week" for environmental reasons, when local authorities decided to implement a "weekly meatless day". Civil servants would eat vegetarian meals one day per week, in recognition of the United Nations' report. Posters were put up by local authorities to encourage the population to take part on vegetarian days, and "veggie street maps" were printed to highlight vegetarian restaurants. In September 2009, schools in Ghent are due to have a weekly <i>veggiedag</i> ("vegetarian day") too.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[189]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Labor_conditions_and_diet">Labor conditions and diet</span></h2>
<p>Some groups, such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=PETA&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="PETA (page does not exist)">PETA</a>, promote vegetarianism as a way to offset poor treatment and working conditions of workers in the contemporary meat industry.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[190]</a></sup> These groups cite studies showing the psychological damage caused by working in the meat industry, especially in factory and industrialised settings, and argue that the meat industry violates its labourers' human rights by assigning difficult and distressing tasks without adequate counselling, training and debriefing.<sup id="cite_ref-labor_193-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-labor-193">[191]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-labor2_194-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-labor2-194">[192]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-labor3_195-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-labor3-195">[193]</a></sup> However, the working conditions of agricultural workers as a whole, particularly non-permanent workers, remain poor and well below conditions prevailing in other economic sectors.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[194]</a></sup> Accidents, including pesticide poisoning, among farmers and plantation workers contribute to increased health risks, including increased mortality.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[195]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/International_Labour_Organization" title="International Labour Organization">International Labour Organization</a>, agriculture is one of the three most dangerous jobs in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[196]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economics_and_diet">Economics and diet</span></h2>
<p>Similar to environmental vegetarianism is the concept of <a href="/wiki/Economic_vegetarianism" title="Economic vegetarianism">economic vegetarianism</a>. An economic vegetarian is someone who practices vegetarianism from either the philosophical viewpoint concerning issues such as public health and curbing world starvation, the belief that the consumption of meat is economically unsound, part of a conscious <a href="/wiki/Simple_living" title="Simple living">simple living</a> strategy or just out of necessity. According to the <a href="/wiki/Worldwatch_Institute" title="Worldwatch Institute">Worldwatch Institute</a>, "Massive reductions in meat consumption in industrial nations will ease their health care burden while improving public health; declining livestock herds will take pressure off rangelands and grainlands, allowing the agricultural resource base to rejuvenate. As populations grow, lowering meat consumption worldwide will allow more efficient use of declining per capita land and water resources, while at the same time making grain more affordable to the world's chronically hungry."<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[197]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Chinese-buddhist-cuisine-taiwan-1.jpg" title="File:Chinese-buddhist-cuisine-taiwan-1.jpg">File:Chinese-buddhist-cuisine-taiwan-1.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Taiwanese Buddhist cuisine</div></div></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<p>A research study conducted on more than 8,000 people, and published in the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=British_Medical_Journal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British Medical Journal (page does not exist)">British Medical Journal</a></i>, suggested that children with an above-average IQ may have a higher chance of becoming vegetarians in their adulthood.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[198]</a></sup> Vegetarians had an average childhood IQ of 105 compared with 100 for non-vegetarians. No difference in IQ score was found between strict vegetarians and those who reported eating <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pescetarianism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pescetarianism (page does not exist)">fish</a> or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Semi-vegetarianism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Semi-vegetarianism (page does not exist)">chicken</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[199]</a></sup>
</p><p>Prejudice researcher Gordon Hodson observes that vegetarians and vegans frequently face <a href="/wiki/Discrimination" title="Discrimination">discrimination</a> because eating meat is held as a cultural norm, as do <a href="/w/index.php?title=Atheism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Atheism (page does not exist)">atheists</a> and <a href="/wiki/Asexuality" title="Asexuality">asexuals</a> because religion and sex hold similar status.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[200]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Gender">Gender</span></h3>
<p>A 1992 market research study conducted by the Yankelovich research organisation concluded that "of the 12.4 million people [in the US] who call themselves vegetarian, 68% are female, while only 32% are male".<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[201]</a></sup>
</p><p>At least one study indicates that vegetarian women are more likely to have female babies. A study of 6,000 pregnant women in 1998 "found that while the national average in Britain is 106 boys born to every 100 girls, for vegetarian mothers the ratio was just 85 boys to 100 girls".<sup id="cite_ref-Babies_204-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Babies-204">[202]</a></sup> Catherine Collins of the British Dietetic Association has dismissed this as a "statistical fluke" given that it is actually the male's <a href="/wiki/XY_sex-determination_system" title="XY sex-determination system">genetic contribution</a> which determines the sex of a baby.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:R&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:R (page does not exist)">Template:R</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Country-specific_information">Country-specific information</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>

</li>
